facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 1678 and 1855 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 1678 and 1855 of 1973. Under Art. 32 of the Constitution for issue of a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner in Writ Petition No. 1678 of 1973 detained since January 15, 1972 pursuant to detention order dated January 14, 1972 by District Magistrate, Burdwan under section 3(2) of MISA 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner in Writ Petition No. 1678 of 1973 is in detention since January 15, 1972 in pursuance of an order dated January 14, 1972, passed under s. 3  2  of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  for short, the Act  by the District Magistrate, Burdwan.

facts.text: Detention order in WP 1678 confirmed by Government on April 12, 1972 under section 12(1) of MISA.

anchor.surface_text: The detention order as companyfirmed by the Government on April 12, 1972 under S. 12  1  of the Act, directs that the detention will companytinue tin the expiration of 12 months from the date of his detention or until the expiry of Defence of India Act, 1971 whichever is later.

facts.text: Detention in WP 1678 to continue for 12 months from date of detention or until expiry of Defence of India Act, 1971, whichever later.

facts.text: District Magistrate, Burdwan passed detention order based on reliable information of detenu's illegal anti-social and prejudicial activities relating to maintenance of supplies and services essential to community.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the records that after receiving reliable information relating to the illegal anti-social and prejudi- cial activities of the above-named detenu-petitioner relating to the maintenance of Supplies and Services essential to the companymunity, the said District Magistrate of Burdwan passed order of detention against him under the provisions of the said Act.

facts.text: Detenu-petitioner described as veteran copper wire criminal in counter-affidavit para 7.

anchor.surface_text: In para 7 of the companynter, it is said that it appears from the records, that the detenu-petitioner is a veteran companyper wire criminal.

facts.text: Theft of 40 kgs underground copper wire cable on December 19, 1971 at 00:30 hrs by detenu with associates Md. Kasim and Hyder Ali from St. Patric School compound, PS Asansol, Dist Burdwan, disrupting telecommunication between Panagarh Army Base Camp and Patna for 6 hours.

anchor.surface_text: That on 19-12--1971 at about 00-30 hrs. You alongwith your associates including  1  Md. Kasim son of Md. Mandal of Kashi Mohalla, P. S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan  2  Hyder Ali son of Bachchu Md. of Talpukuria, P. S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan, took away 40 kgs. underground companyper wire cable used for the purpose of tele-communication service from St. Patric School companypound, P. S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan. As a result of this theft important telecommunication service between Panagarh Army Base Camp and Patna was totally disrupted for long 6 hours causing much inconvenience to the people.

facts.text: Second theft of 80 kgs underground copper wire cable between 20:30 hrs on December 22, 1971 and 00:30 hrs on December 23, 1971 by detenu with associates Md. Kasim and Hyder Ali from St. Patric School compound, disrupting telecommunication Panagarh Army Base Camp and Patna for 8 hours.

anchor.surface_text: That between 28.30 hrs. on 22-12-71 and 00.30 hrs. on 23-12-71 you along with your associates including  1  Md. Kasim son of Md. Mandal of Kasimohalla P. S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan  2  Hyder All, son of Bachcha Md. of Talpukuria, P. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan took away 80 kgs. underground companyper wire cable used for the purpose of telecommunication service from St. Patric School companypound, P. S. Asansol, Dist. Burdwan. By your act important telecommunication service Panagarh between Army Base Camp and Patna was totally disrupted for long 8 hours to the sufferings of the people.

facts.text: Jiten Ninia (petitioner WP 1855) hails from Dumka, works as temporary loading cooly in colliery, no education, no landed property, addicted to wine, gambles, associates with criminals, commits petty thefts including P&T and DVC cables, dangerous and desperate character.

anchor.surface_text: Jiten Niniaoriginally hails from Dumka. He works temporarilyas loading companyly in the companyliery. He has got numbereducationgot numberlanded property. He is addicted to wine and indulges in gambling in the area. The place where he is staying being infested by criminals and due lo his close association with them. he developed criminal propensity. His mode of living is beyond his means and as such he started companymitting petty thefts against property. He came in companytact with companyper wire criminals of the locality and started companymitting theft in respect of P.T. telecommunication cables and D.V.C. cables in the area. He is dangerous and desperate in character

issues.text: Whether the period of detention made co-extensive with the expiry of the Defence of India Act, 1971 is indefinite and violates Article 22(7)(b)?

anchor.surface_text: 54Sup CI/74 The period of detention fixed under the impugned order is indefinite and uncertain inasmuch as it has been made company extensive with another indefinite and uncertain period viz., the life of the Defence of India Act, 1971. holdings.text: The expression 'Supplies and Services' in s. 3(1)(a)(iii) of the Act are to be construed pragmatically; telecommunication copper wires/cables are both supplies and services essential to the community.

anchor.surface_text: Contention 1 does number appear to be tenable. The expression Supplies and Services in s. 3  1   a   iii  of the Act are to be companystrued pragmatically in the companytext of each case, with due stress on the phrase essential to the life of the companymunity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pragmatic construction considering context 'essential to community'; dictionary definition of supply; precedents like Blackpool Corp. and Jagdish Prasad interpreting supplies/services disjunctively or coinciding.

holdings.text: The period of detention fixed co-extensive with the expiry of the Defence of India Act, 1971 does not violate Article 22(7)(b).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept companytention  ii  because this matter stands companycluded by this Courts judgment in Fagu Shah etc. etc. v. State of West Bengal 3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concluded by binding precedent in Fagu Shah v. State of West Bengal; maximum period linked to emergency duration adequate for preventive detention object.

holdings.text: In habeas corpus proceedings under Article 32, the proper counter-affidavit should be filed by the District Magistrate or a senior officer who dealt with the case; however, omission is not fatal where mala fides allegations are imprecise and deficient in particulars.

anchor.surface_text: This obligation stems from the well-settled principle that once a Rule Nisi is issued on habeas companypus motion, by the Court, the onus is on the State to show that the liberty of the detenu has been taken away in accordance with procedure established by law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Onus on State post Rule Nisi; requirement not empty formality per precedents like Shaik Hanif and Jagdish Prasad; here, imprecise mala fides saved order but circumstance against it.

holdings.text: Non-communication of material/information portraying detenu as veteran copper wire criminal violates Article 22(5), depriving effective representation; detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Secretary in his affidavit has disclosed that therewas reliable information and other material,-in addition to whatwas companymunicated to the detenu before the detaining authorities,in regard to the anti social and prejudicial activities of the petitioner showing how he was a veteran companyper wire criminal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Material contributed to subjective satisfaction; not privileged under Art.22(6); full grounds/material must be communicated for effective representation under Art.22(5).

holdings.text: Non-communication of material portraying detenu as desperate, dangerous character and veteran copper wire stealer violates Article 22(5) by prejudicing effective representation; detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: In any case, omission to companymunicate this material to the detenu must have seriously prejudiced him in exercising his right of making an effective representation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisclosed material influenced detention decision and germane to grounds; non-communication seriously prejudiced representation right under Art.22(5); no privilege claimed.

anchor.surface_text: Thus in Blackpool Corporation v. Locker 1 , it was held that the provisions of housing accommodation was within the ambit of supplies and services in Regulation 51 1  of the Defence  General  Regulation 1939. In Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar 2 , this Court had the occasion to consider the meaning of Supplies and Services in this statutory provision in the context of hoarding and black-marketing in foodgrains

precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of housing accommodation was within the ambit of supplies and services in Regulation 51(1) of the Defence (General) Regulation 1939

precedents.citation: Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar 2

anchor.surface_text: In Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar 2 , this Court had the occasion to consider the meaning of Supplies and Services in this statutory provision in the context of hoarding and black-marketing in foodgrains It is, therefore, not necessary to dilate on this subject any further. It will be sufficient to extract here what the Bench, constituted by both of us, said on the point . . . all supplies are not services and all services are not supplies but the complex needs and amenities of modern life and the multifarious obligations of a welfare state mingle supplies and services so much that the concentric circle geometry becomes a misleading stroke of gullibility in his jural area.

precedents.case_name: Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'Supplies and Services' in the context of hoarding and black-marketing in foodgrains; supplies and services can overlap in modern context
precedents.cited_holding: all supplies are not services and all services are not supplies but the complex needs... mingle supplies and services... essential commodity is at once a supply and a service

precedents.citation: Fagu Shah etc. etc. v. State of West Bengal 3

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept contention ii because this matter stands concluded by this Courts judgment in Fagu Shah etc. etc. v. State of West Bengal 3 . The argument therein was that the expression maximum period in Article 22 7 b connotes a definite period reckoned in terms of years, months or days and that no period can be said to be maximum period unless it is possible to predicate its beginning and end in terms of years, months or days and that since the determination of the period of detention, namely, expiry of Defence of India Act, 1971, is dependent upon revocation of Proclamation of Emergency, the period 1 1948 1, K. B. 349. 2 Writ Petition No. 1972 of 1973. Writ Petitions Nos. 41, 106, 113, 214, 441 and 621 of 1973. decided on 20-12-1973. fixed under s. 13 of the Act is not the maximum period as visualised by Art. 22 7 b Mathew J., who spoke for the majority, negatived this contention in these terms as the object of preventive detention is to prevent persons from acting in a manner pre-judicial to the maintenance of internal security, public order or supplies or services essential to the community or other objects specified in entry 9 of List I the power to detain must be adequate in point of duration to achieve the object.

precedents.case_name: Fagu Shah v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: the period of detention tied to expiry of Defence of India Act, 1971 is a valid 'maximum period' under Article 22(7)(b)
precedents.cited_holding: the maximum period of detention with reference to the duration of an emergency does not abdicate Parliament's power; it is fixed by Parliament in s.13

precedents.citation: Shaik Hanif v. State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: In Shaik Hanif v. State of West Bengal 1  this Court had pointed out that in return to a Rule Nisi issued by this Court in a habeas corpus petition, the proper person to file the counter-affidavit is the District Magistrate who had passed the order of detention under s. 3 of the Act, and, if for some good reason the Magistrate is not available, the next best thing would be to furnish the affidavit of a Senior Officer who personally dealt with the case of the detenu in the Government Secretariat, or had put it to the Minister for orders. Our democratic Constitution inhibits blanket and arbitrary deprivation of a persons liberty by authority.

precedents.case_name: Shaik Hanif v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: proper person to file counter-affidavit in habeas corpus is District Magistrate or senior officer who dealt with the case

precedents.citation: Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar supra

anchor.surface_text: In Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar supra , also where the counter-affidavit had been sworn by an Assistant of the Home Department, not with personal knowledge, but paper wisdom, the Court, both of us, constituting the Bench, expressed itself in the same strain, with added emphasis, thus It is difficult to appreciate why in return to rule nisi in a habeas corpus motion, it is not thought serious enough even where liberty of a citizen is choked off, to get the District Magistrate to explain his subjective satisfaction and the grounds therefor.

precedents.case_name: Jagdish Prasad v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: counter-affidavit by officer without personal knowledge insufficient; must be by DM or senior officer with knowledge
precedents.cited_holding: Mechanical affidavits by some one handy in the Secretariat cannot be regarded This is not a mere punctilio of procedure but a probative requirement of substance.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: This obligation stems from the well-settled principle that once a Rule Nisi is issued on habeas companypus motion, by the Court, the onus is on the State to show that the liberty of the detenu has been taken away in accordance with procedure established by law.
